channel.title: R on Academic
channel.description: Recent content in R on Academic

item.title: Python with Reticulate
item.description:
Let’s download some packages.

And calculate European call.

{python echo=TRUE} import math import numpy as np from timeit import default_timer as timer start = timer() S = 100 K = 105 T = 1 r = 0.05 sigma = 0.2 I = 100000 z = np.random.standard_normal(I) ST = S * np.exp((r-0.5*sigma**2)T + sigma math.sqrt(T)z) hT = np.maximum(ST - K, 0) C0 = math.exp(-rT)*np.mean(hT) print(‘Value of %5.3f.’ % C0) end = timer() print(‘Elapsed time in seconds %5.3f.’ % (end - start))

start = Sys.time()
S = 100
K = 105 
T = 1 
r = 0.05
sigma = 0.2
I = 100000
z = rnorm(I)
ST = S * exp((r-0.5*sigma**2)*T + sigma * sqrt(T)*z)
hT = pmax(ST - K, 0)
C0 = exp(-r*T)*mean(hT)
C0
## [1] 8.031604
end = Sys.time() - start
print(paste("Elapsed time in seconds:", end))
## [1] "Elapsed time in seconds: 0.0201637744903564"

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description:
R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)
##      speed           dist       
##  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
##  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
##  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
##  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
##  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
##  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00
fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
fit
## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)
## 
## Coefficients:
## (Intercept)        speed  
##     -17.579        3.932

Including Plots

You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:

par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1))
pie(
  c(280, 60, 20),
  c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'),
  col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'),
  init.angle = -50, border = NA
)

Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.
